text:
- Hi, everybody, I'm Stephen
Manley, I'm the CTO at Druva.
- Hi everyone, my name's David Gildea,
and I'm a VP of Product at Druva.
We got a bowl of questions,
you wanna go first?

- "Describe Amazon Bedrock's
impact in five words or less."
- Rapidly built dynamic service.
I got it in four, crushed it.

But I mean, but yeah, to
me, that's the big thing,

is it let us rapidly build
a service that evolves.
This is right up your alley,

"Can you explain the
evolution of Dru from concept

to its current capabilities
using Amazon Bedrock?"
- Hm, oh, great question.

So, it really kinda started
with just experimenting
with some generative AI.

Dru is our, you know,
capability that helps customers
get the best out of our products.

So, the idea of having generative
AI that could, you know,
maybe answer questions for you,
so starting with a Q&A kind of approach
was the easiest place to start.

So, immediately customers
wanted to see about their data,

so we moved from Q&A only
to start adding in some data
into that.

So, ask questions about
your backup failures,
ask questions about, you know,
potential threats in your environment,

how can you learn more
about your environment?

But just ask the questions
in the way you understand.

So, Bedrock was key in that
with the ability to have lots
of different models that could understand
more complex intent than just Q&A.
And then the last step of the evolution

is starting to add in more
complexity where we, you know,

questions are more
multifaceted, so it's, you know,
"Tell me about this and this."
Or, "Can you do X, Y, and Z?"
So, you know, things like Knowledge Bases

have really helped, and then
the more advanced models

and a range of models helped
kind of that evolution
from just Q&A, to Q&A plus data,
and then adding an extra layer of context
and intelligence on top.
- A lot of times,

I don't know the question
I should be asking, right?

So, it's nice that I can ask
a question and get the answer,

but it's even better if you
can sort of guide me towards,
"What you should be asking is this."

- Yeah.
- And so,

how did you pull, how did you
make that happen with Bedrock?
- You know, it's a great question,

and one of the first
things was seeing the kind

of questions customers were
asking, that was the first step.

So we could, you know, we
knew that they were trying

to understand the threat,
they were trying to understand

when something has gone wrong
or if there was a breach,
so that was immediately, you know,
a challenge we had to solve.

So, doing things like using
Knowledge Bases in Bedrock
with a lot of MITRE ATT&CK information,

a lot of information
around specific threats
to your environment.
So when a customer asked a question,
we could then preemptively pull out pieces
of information we thought would be helpful
for the next step.

So, as you mentioned, quite
often people don't know

the steps they need to go
through to understand something,
and we want to educate them in the chat,

you know, "Here's a threat
in your environment,
you really should know about it."
So, it becomes both a resolution tool
and an education tool at the same time.

Quite often people don't
have an in-depth knowledge
of the threat they're trying to fix,

you know, they're busy
with a lot of other tasks
that they're doing as well,

so you want to make sure
they leave successfully,

they have all the information
to make the right decision,

and they can solve the
problem and the threat

and make sure their
company's protected, so.

- "Quickly walk us through
the architecture of Dru
and how does it integrate
with Druva's existing AWS infrastructure?"

- That is something that
is really important to me,
and I think when I talk to our customers,
everybody is really reasonably afraid

of what you'd call the bag on
the side architecture, right?

The way lots and lots of
products did cloud initially,

"Well, I'm gonna add
cloud, and it's this"-

- Mhm.
- And you could tell

that it was added on, it's
a separate management,

it's separate security, the
whole thing was sort of awkward
to begin with.

And when people came out with
real cloud native solutions,

like we did for sort of data
protection, data security,

they went, "Oh, that's what
it's supposed to feel like,
it scales automatically, it just works."

- Yep.
- So, as we've done gen AI,
it's been a lot of that same thing.

Everything goes through the
same authentication mechanism,

right, so, you as a customer,
when you log into Druva,
and you're gonna use, you know, Dru,

it's the exact same
permissions, exact same access
as if you were going to click the buttons,
or download reports, or do anything else,

you don't get access to any
more than you would've had,
you don't get access to any less.
So, that security model's the same.

Same on the privacy, right,
there's no data access
that you have from a privacy perspective
that's any different than you had.

And so it's one of the
things I've really liked
about how we've used Bedrock, you know,
and what you and your team did
is making sure that it's an integral part
of the architecture,
as opposed to something totally separate.

Because, you know, if I
look forward 18 months,
24 months, 36 months, more and more
of what our customers are going to do

we'll be going through the
generative AI interface,
it won't be going through

what I would consider that
legacy style interface-

- Classic UI.
- Classic, right,
where you're clicking in a bunch of places
And to me, that's the biggest difference

that we're trying to bring
to bear into this market

every time I pick up a
new piece of software,
one I don't use very often, I feel dumb.
- And I have to relearn it,

I never want a Druva
customer to sort of go,
"Oh my gosh, why is this so hard?"

- Yeah.
- It should, to your point,
you should just be able to log in and say,
"Look, I'm just trying to get this done,

I'm trying to recover
from a ransomware attack,

I'm trying to see if there's
a ransomware attack."

Tell me what you want-
- Yeah.
- And I'll guide you through it,

as opposed to, "Let me send
you to three weeks of training
so you can figure out"-

- Yeah.
- "how to use my product."
And the only way you get there is if this
is an integral part of the product-

- Gotcha.
- and becomes more
and more fundamental.

- I think one of the great
things that Amazon have done

with Bedrock is it's architected
like everything else,

and so we constantly have
conversations with customers,
and they're rightly concerned, but

we can say it's architected
in the exact same way,
security's handled in the exact same way,

then straightaway people
have comfort that actually,
well, there's nothing different.

- Right.
- You know,

everything's handled-
- Just another component.
- Exactly, it's another component,
rather than being something brand new,

and usually when you
put AI onto something,

people get concerned and think,
"Well, this is different,

and it works differently."
- Yeah.
- So I think that's a great benefit for us
that we can just utilize it everywhere
and not think this is something different
that we have to handle in a different way.

- Yeah, the moment software
stops making you feel dumb-

- Yeah.
- and starts just doing
what you want it to do, I think again,
that changes the world.
- Yep, absolutely.
